To ensure proper functioning, Pittsburg Operations emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place that would require a modified emergency response.

CA Region II LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the emergency plan for the Pittsburg Operations site has been coordinated and verified. Pittsburg Operations also coordinates our plans and actions with local agencies and industrial mutual aid groups, which provide Pittsburg Operations with additional emergency response capability.


6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Improving safety is a continuous process at Pittsburg Operations.  PHA's, Compliance Audits, Technology Reviews, Facility Self-Assessments and Management System Reviews, Incident Investigations, Emergency Response Drills and employee participation are a primary means for identifying opportunities to improve safety.  Structural seismic upgrades, materials of construction upgrades, installing additional process instrumentation and/or process controls, and conducting Hazard Awareness training are typical of currently planned changes to improve safety at the facility.  As another example of Pittsburg Operations' commitment to continuous improvement in safety, the site was CalOSHA Voluntary Protection Plan (VPP) Star certified in 2013 and recertified in 2017.

Additional information regarding process descriptions, Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenario impact maps, public receptors, etc., is available at the Pittsburg Operations Site.

r views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  The site has safety teams, which involve employees as leaders in facilitating team efforts. In addition, Pittsburg Operations employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. Safe job performance is required for each of the jobs at the site.

Contractors
Pittsburg Operations hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Pittsburg Operations has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also required to inform Pittsburg Operations of any hazards they may introduce at the site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.


4. Five-year Accident History
Pittsburg Operations has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases due to the site's release prevention policies.  There is only one accident on the site’s five-year accident history.
On May 13th, 2021 a minor chlorine leak resulted in an injury (OSHA recordable) to a Corteva employee. Approximately three pounds of chlorine was released as the result of packing failure on one of the valves.  The injured employee was looking for the leak without wearing the appropriate PPE.  As a result of the incident, Operations was retrained on PPE requirements and new equipment was purchased to facilitate the identification of leak points. There were no off-site consequences.


5. Emergency Response Plan
Pittsburg Operations utilizes a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency respons

vious training in maintenance practices are utilized to carry out appropriate maintenance.  These personnel are also offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Pittsburg Operations to safely manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted by appropriate personnel as a regular practice at Pittsburg Operations.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Pittsburg Operations conducts self assessments of the management systems designed to ensure RMP requirements on a regular basis.  These self assessments are carried out at least once every 3 years by each facility.  Any corrective actions identified as a result of the self assessments are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.

Incident Investigation
Pittsburg Operations promptly and carefully investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Pittsburg Operations truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express thei

le to plant operations personnel.

Process Hazard Analysis
Pittsburg Operations conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the covered processes are identified and effectively controlled.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses include Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analysis (RC/PHA), Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), Reactive Chemical Reviews, and Project Safety & Loss Prevention Reviews.  Studies utilize an appropriate team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering, maintenance and process operations and are revalidated on a regular basis.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis, where a response is required, are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within Pittsburg Operations' covered processes, written operating procedures are maintained.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  This information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to plant operations personnel.

Training
Pittsburg Operations has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures and safe work practices associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least once every 3 years, and more frequently as needed, for required process and safety topics.

Mechanical Integrity
Pittsburg Operations carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure safe and reliable operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, critical instruments, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. lso committed to responding to emergencies resulting from accidental releases in order to mitigate the release and any associated consequences.


2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
The primary activity at Pittsburg Operations is agricultural chemical manufacturing.  Pittsburg Operations has six regulated substances present at the site.  These substances include ammonia (aqueous), ammonia (anhydrous), chlorine, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), hydrogen fluoride (anhydrous) and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous).  Ammonia (anhydrous) is used in pollution control equipment for a boiler.  Ammonia (aqueous) is used in making an agricultural herbicidal intermediate.  Chlorine is used in making of intermediate and finished products for agricultural applications and is a byproduct of these processes.  Hydrogen chloride is made as a co-product of some of the agricultural product manufacturing processes.  Hydrogen fluoride is used to make an agricultural intermediate.  The site manages sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) railcars for a site tenant that uses the sulfur dioxide to manufacture an agricultural product. 


3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program
Pittsburg Operations has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  Pittsburg Operations was designed and constructed in accordance with RAGAGEP.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the site.

Process Safety Information
Pittsburg Operations maintains detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Examples include; Material Safety Data Sheets, piping and instrumentation diagrams, equipment specification sheets, reactive chemicals testing reports, and corrosion reports. Risk Management Plan Executive Summary for Corteva Agriscience, Pittsburg Operations

Revision History:

April 2023 - Resubmitted RMP due primarily to OCA update.  However, several changes are captured in this update as follows.

a) 310 Block Operations:
Removed a unit operation within the 310 Block Operations that handled hydrogen fluoride and sulfur dioxide.  The unit operation was sold and is being operated by a company other than Corteva.  The 310 Block Operations no longer handles sulfur dioxide but continues to handle hydrogen fluoride at reduced amounts.  The facility is already, and remains, a Program 3 stationary source with accident prevention programs in place. 

b) Site Logistics
The site’s worst case scenario is now hydrogen fluoride and moves from the 310 Block Operations unit operation to the Site Logistics unit operation.  The facility is already, and remains, a Program 3 stationary source with accident prevention programs in place. 

c) WCS / ACS
The new site WCS for hydrogen fluoride is a Site Logistics scenario.  The new ARS for sulfur dioxide is a Site Logistics scenario.  The ARS for hydrogen fluoride does not change and is a 310 Block scenario.

Note: Unit Operations included in Federal RMP due to interconnectivity rule.  Section 1.17 includes actual inventory (below threshold quantity)
520 Block Operations [Hydrogen Chloride]
560 Block Operations [Chlorine]


1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Corteva Agriscience, Pittsburg Operations is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Pittsburg Operation’s comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at Pittsburg Operations.
